required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The First ERAS Protocol for Cesarean Delivery in Serbia at the University Hospital
clinical_study.official_title: Implementation of ERAS Protocol for Cesarean Delivery in Clinical Center Vojvodina

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to help us with ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) Protocol for Cesarean Delivery implementation with goal to improve patient satisfaction and decrease length of stay at hospital. This will improve patient treatment and decrease total hospital costs.

detailed_description.textblock: ERAS assumes cooperation between obstetricians, anesthesiologists and parturient. This is the new concept because patient have an active role in the whole process. Pregnant patient receives the first information about ERAS from obstetrician and anesthesiologist before the scheduled cesarean delivery. Patient condition optimization is necessary. Antibiotic prophylaxis, no bowel preparation and arriving to the hospital on the day of surgery are basic principles. All patients are done under spinal anesthesia. DVT (Deep Venous Thrombosis) prophylaxis starts postoperatively. Early mobilization, early oral intake and urinary catheter removal on the day of surgery with multimodal analgesia is mandatory.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured from postoperative day (PO) Day 0 to PO day 3 (72 hours)
primary_outcome.description: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain assessment (scale from 0-10). Score 0 to 5 is satisfactory pain control. Score 6 to 10 is not a good pain control and is necessary to add medication.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: PO Day 0 until time of discharge PO Day 3-4 (72-96 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Length of stay might influence on cost savings. Investigator expects discharge hospital will be on the PO day 3.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured from the Cesarean Delivery to 6 weeks postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: Inadequate postoperative treatment could cause chronic pain which could be the reason for post- partal depression development. Six weeks after delivery investigator will call mothers for interview and fill the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale. Score 10 and more is suspect for depression risk.

arm_group.description: Perioperative management follows the ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) protocol
Perioperative management follows the conventional program

intervention.description: No routine bowel preparation Antibiotics prophylaxis PONV (Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting) prophylaxis Spinal anesthesia Post- Cesarean analgesia (Acetaminophen 1g IV q6h, Tramadol 50mg IV q6h, Quadratus lumborum Block Oral pain relief medication Pain scores every day (VAS) Hospital length of stay Patient satisfaction

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All healthy patients from 18-45 years for scheduled Cesarean Delivery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age younger then 18 years old and older then 45 years
- Urgent and emergent Cesarean Delivery
- Preeclampsia
- Contraindications for spinal anesthesia
- Abnormal placentation

overall_official.affiliation: Obstetric and Gynecology Hospital, Novi Sad, Serbia

results_reference.citation: Gamez BH, Habib AS. Predicting Severity of Acute Pain After Cesarean Delivery: A Narrative Review. Anesth Analg. 2018 May;126(5):1606-1614. doi: 10.1213/ANE.0000000000002658. Review.
